Geodetic CRS:  WGS84(DD)







This map shows the spread of service requests called on homeless encampments in NYC between 2000 until March 22, 2024. While the COVID pandemic had a significant impact on the number of encampments in the city, the data is helpful in understanding relatively high areas of homelessness in the city. It is clear that Manhattan has the highest number of reported encampments, so let’s zoom in on it.





We can see that some neighborhoods have had many reports of camps and some none at all. If we aggregate the data we will have a better time visually assessing any spatial autocorrelation.





We can see that many community districts in Manhattan have had little to no reports of encampments, while others have a concentrated number. We can better visualise the data if we log the number of encampments.





Much better, we can better visually assess the distribution of reported encampments in the community districts.
From here, we can calculate the Moran’s I which is a statistical test that measures the spatial autocorrelation of an aggregate variable.



    Monte-Carlo simulation of Moran I

data:  mn_sf$n 
weights: mn_nbw  
number of simulations + 1: 1000 

statistic = -0.013353, observed rank = 701, p-value = 0.299
alternative hypothesis: greater


\(H_O\): No spatial autocorrelation, I is close to 0
\(H_A\): Spatial autocorrelation, I \(\neq\) 0.
With a Moran’s I of -0.013, we observe a weak negative spatial autocorrelation. However, as the p-value of 0.299 is relatively large, we fail to reject the null hypothesis; the number of reported homeless encampments is not spatially autocorrelated in Manhattan community districts as per this data and our analysis. This could be due to many factors, the lack of robust data on homelessness. Temporal bias could also be an issue, as the data is spread out over four years. Aggregate bias could also have an effect on the results; analysis of point-pattern data using K-cross analyses would have been more appropriate.

title: US States
text: From the plot, we can see that there is a significant difference in the number of shelters and housing for people experiencing homelessness between states. California seems to have eight times more homeless housing projects than the national average. Minnesota is one of the few Midwestern states who are above the national average. However, this map does not tell the whole story, as California has the highest homeless population in the country. However, this plot can give insight but must be viewed in a larger context. One must also take into account the homeless per capita numbers as well as population density. It would be interesting to calculate the Moran’s I of the number of missions per homeless population.

This exercise compares The New York Times headlines between Palestine and Israel. While they refer to the same land, the names used carry nuances, which is reflected in the differences of coverage.
The graph below shows shows the frequency of mentions in headlines between Israel and Palestine (demonyms included). We can clearly see an enormous gap between coverage. The bar graph also shows that almost half of the mentions of Palestine are related to mentions of Israel, while mentions of both do not constitute a significant portion of Israel’s mentions. Israel is more likely to be mentioned when Palestine is mentioned but Palestine is not likely to be mentioned when Israel is mentioned.

# ℹ 6 more variables: pub_date <dttm>, news_desk <chr>, section <chr>,
#   year <dbl>, country <chr>, word <chr>


The proportion of unique words can inform us of the variety in which the headlines speak of the country. This could be owed to a niche focused journalism or a more widespread coverage. However, since there is a stark difference in headlines for each country, it is difficult to be conclusive.





The standard deviation of the word count of articles could be a measure of the scope of journalism. Higher standard deviation could indicated a more diverse set of topics while a lower one could imply a more focused discussion. It can also mean that there is less consistency with the length of the articles.





This temporal graph allows us to see how sparseley or consistently the country is being covered. We can also better see the ranges of word counts.
